displayed_text: Family Member: That’s why we made you the copies… Doctor: Yeah. Thank you. Family Member: You can see all the ingredients. Doctor: For now you can use it, but then I will compare the ingredients to make sure it doesn’t affect anything. Patient: I think I’ll just wait before I start adding that stuff on there because some of it’s a little pricy. Doctor: You need a few weeks. Oh yeah. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: And if I don’t need it I’m not gonna be able to take it… Doctor: And then if you have to stop it, it’s kind of pointless to get it. Patient: Yeah, exactly. Family Member: We’ll wait until we know what’s going on before we do the targeted stuff Doctor: Yeah I agree. Okay. Patient: We’ll know in a couple weeks anyway.

Patient: I think so. I think so, 'cause-- Doctor: Yeah, because the last time your PSA came down and, you know, I think this tearing, like I said, it could possibly be from the chemotherapy, so-- Patient: I mean, if I'm doin' good on it, Doctor: It’s very much Patient: -let's keep goin'. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I know I have an imaging scheduled for, what was it S____, the--? Healthcare Professional: Uh, we're going to do it the fourteeth. Patient: Fourteenth? Healthcare Professional: So it's two weeks from today. Doctor: So two weeks from now. Healthcare Professional: And then treatment on the twenty first.

Family Member: Hormones - Uh is he getting more medicine today? Doctor: Well he got that shot; that shot lasts for three months Family Member: OHH! Patient: For three months? Oh, okay. I thought it was for three weeks. Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months. Family Member: Three months. So at what point does the prostate shrink? Doctor: That’s our hope. Family Member: OHH! Patient: So should I be wearing this catheter for a while then? Doctor: Well because again it could be as early as this week that they feel like you can pee on your own. But if that’s what they’re going to be testing - Patient: And they cannot test it any other way except by pulling it out.

Patient: Yeah, I saw that. Doctor: Today’s is not bad. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It might be an opportunity to put on a second drug on top of this current drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you would stay on this, but we would pile on something else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, M___’s lookin’ to see. We have about two trials to consider. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But one of them, I just gotta make sure. The one that I am thinking of, I have to make sure that there is an opening. You know how the drill goes. Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: But the good news is the scans were just done. It really does not show. Patient: That’s good.

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And your cancer, really, is not showing any major activity, so. Family Member: Great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Uh, uh, the PSA looks normal. Doctor: Well, it’s forty-three, though. Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s not a whole lot, uh, for change. And your scans have not shown any major change. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know? The ones she did in, uh, end of November or December, whenever you saw her last. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, so based on that, I wouldn’t change anything. I think you should stick with, uh, the Lupron should be continued and the bone medication. Are they doing both of those?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s a reasonable ---- Family Member: But it wouldn’t stay down if things weren’t okay --- if you were getting worse, either. I mean, is there a false – Doctor: I mean, occasionally we have a patient where all the disease is getting better, and then one spot starts to grow. That’s where, that would be the one place we kind of fall through the cracks. But, usually, - the PSA represents the sum of all of the cancers in your body are contributing to it. So, usually, when it’s going down, we sort of think that the sum is going down. And, when it’s going up, we think that it’s starting to be resistant. Um. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: But it’s an indication of prostate cancer, and as far as we know, that’s all that he has. Doctor: Right. Right. Family Member: Even though, it’s in different places. Doctor: Right. And, sometimes when the PSA goes up, the scans can still look stable, because they’re not as sensitive to changes as the, as the – Patient: As the chemical – Doctor: Blood count. Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Have fun. Enjoy the weather. Patient: Let’s see. Six weeks is going to put us in middle of July? Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: End of July.

Family Member: Open trucks. Doctor: I have a patient, one of my patients is a guy with a lot of money, and he and his wife do this. But, you know, they do it like only people with a lot of money can do it. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: And he’s like, oh, yeah, we’re going and we stay in these tents. Patient: Oh, you can. Doctor: And his wife’s like, yeah, they’re not really tents, though. They like have king-size bed. You know? They’re like- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So they’re like, not like the tent I’ve got. Pop-up and sleep on an air mattress. Patient: They have stuff- Family Member: Right. Patient: They have stuff out there where people can stay out there. I wouldn’t stay out there, man. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Right. Doctor: -because you have had surgery. You have had radiation? Patient: Oh yeah. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: So you've got a PSA, you've got disease. So knowing where it is doesn't necessarily help me now. Patient: Right. Doctor: But if something's obviously seen on an additional scan, you know, we have clinical studies that we could think about. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we have one study where folks you know less than three spots. And as long as one is in bone, we radiate pinpoint radiation, the spots that we see- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -and half the people get of medicine that goes in their bloodstream that goes to cancer in the bone. Patient: Right.

Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling. Doctor: That’s – I was going to do a drive-by and get his stinking ladder. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Let her shoot you up, my friend. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m going to get this rolling with Dr. ___. Patient: So it seems to me though that - Doctor: Yeah? Patient: I come off the Xtandi now; I’m not having, I’m not taking anything to treat the cancer. Doctor: Yeah, right, until you get to the next one, which is this radium or Xofigo. It starts with another “X” name. So don’t get confused. So it’s not Xtandi; it’s Xofigo. Patient: But it would seem to me it makes more sense to keep taking Xtandi till I’m on that treatment. Doctor: You would think so but your cancer has figured it out. (pause) Family Member: So could it start like the first of January and then -

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm,hmm. Doctor: So we (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: If the PSA is anything significant Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Then maybe we would get scans just to have that knowledge. A CT scan and bone scan. Patient: Right. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then to start hormone therapy and to have a consult with radiation and I’m… it’s okay to have a consult with them. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: I wouldn’t necessarily start the radiation until you get better control. Patient: Right. Doctor: Which will hopefully you’ve made some progress

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 3 years (2 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 3 years (2 years but less than 3 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you see him or is he on tour? Patient: I saw, no, you know, he’s having some uh medical problems Doctor: Oh, no. Patient: Are we in the cone of silence here? Doctor: Well, you’re on. Hey. Could you guys, can you guys put down the thingy? The, the cut this part out? Patient: Uh, I can tell you, I can tell you when we’re walking out. Healthcare Professional: They are moving. Doctor: Yes. Healthcare Professional: That one moved that way. Doctor: So just uh can you put us on mute a minute? Thank you. Patient: Pardon? Doctor: Does your ex know?

Patient: And how soon would that start? Doctor: Uh that would be more—again, based on scans and scheduling. Patient: Okay and then who’s going to order the scans? Doctor: So that’s what I’ve got to talk to Dr. G__ about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you’ve already got the test scans, what’s the plan? Because we need to get pictures to sort of say yes, you’ve progressed. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean I could do that. You know I just want to make sure that if he’s you know ultimately if he’s going to get you chemotherapy and the closer you get to there and that can be given anywhere, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know we might just let that system do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If that’s where you’ve had them before for comparison sakes, then - Patient: I haven’t had chemo there.

Patient: For a couple of days. Doctor: Yeah it’s that whole universal precaution. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Double flush your toilet. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It would be better if you had some sort of bleach product in your bathroom or your kitchen. Patient: Sure. Doctor: It’s probably better you don’t share your glasses. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So common sense stuff Patient: Okay. Doctor: would be important.

Patient: What’s the Doctor: -that it may happen right after the first – Patient: What’s the, yeah, how about enlightening me on how much time are we talking about before - Doctor: So, so my plan right now is to give you about two or three courses and do a repeat scan. Patient: That’s uh - Doctor: So one time every three weeks is called one cycle. So today if you get it, that’s your first cycle of treatment. Next treatment will be due in three weeks from today. Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. And if it’s working, if things are shrinking in there, we keep going. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: On an average people get six. The typical sort of maximum if people are having a tremendous benefit and doing fine with it, you know I can go up to ten. But, but we’ll see how it goes. Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles)
